review_title: Great Research University, Science Doesn't Pay
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in London, England
pros: The people are smart, motivated, and conducting world-leading research. The environment lives and breathes innovation, and everybody is interesting and interested in the latest and greatest research. The salary is the best in the UK and London for postdocs. Working at Imperial opens up doors anywhere in the world, in this respect, the career opportunities are fantastic.
cons: The expectation is to always be pushing as hard as possible. People work extremely long hours, and it can be very competitive - far more so than Oxbridge, which can make it lonely. Opportunities for tenure-track positions at Imperial are limited for postdocs and most are expected to leave after a few years. London is an expensive city to live in on a postdoc salary, especially if raising a family. The salary does not compare to that of the private sector.

review_title: Good people, terrible administration, unbearable politics, disgraceful outlook to education
pros: Excellent place, wonderful minds and scientists. Great place for students (they have a lot of support, and are treated like customers). Incredible location in London.
cons: Terrible office spaces, outdated buildings and resources, the administration is impossible to deal with, and the management is locked inside a special building and is completely detached from the actual situation at the university. Outreach and PR are very active making everything seem perfect, but if you look under the carpet, it is just a place full of disappointed people looking forward to leaving, most of them sad that all this potential is wasted. It is wonderful for very few who are at the right place at the right time, or part of the right clique, but in general the university is in disarray. There are literally offices with ceilings dripping and falling apart. There are few huge, and beautiful lecture halls (to keep the image to the students and the outside worlds) but most of the departments are suffering. Everybody expects it will drop massively in rankings in the next 10-15 years unless there is a change of direction.

pros: Prestige. Outsiders worship its reputation
cons:
-Training is not in depth and thorough, leaving entitled graduates failed to equip key techniques and concepts, so as to stand on their feet once landing in a job, based on my experience in the program studied
- Among the rotation to different labs, some do not welcome students in my and my programmate case. Also, the rotation is unstructured and the quality of training you received varies from lab to lab. Some not able to pinpoint what techniques you will learn in such rotation. Some not able to set a clear project before taking a student. Labs should be taken out from the list of rotation given to student if they do not have the personnel/ project given. It could be a waste of time. One should be very careful when you meet your potential PI and supervisor, even though things may not be seen within such short and brief period of time. Also, please talk to your programmates or graduates, who have rotated to the labs you are of interested. The representatives or program director is likely to have some connections with them.

review_title: A personal experience form a PhD student
pros:
IC London is a well-known international institution, where you will find some of the top researchers in any field. During your PhD you will have the opportunity to learn a lot, from your colleagues and courses that will be free. It is likely that you will be able to collaborate in high impact publications.
If you want to follow a carrier in academic research it will look great in your CV.
cons:
As a PhD student you will be completely under control of your supervisor. In that sense you are completely exposed to the whims of your supervisor. Probably you will be lucky and have a good supervisor. However, in a small proportion of cases, some supervisor seem to have PhD students because they don't pay for them directly from their grants and they only care about the their name as a last author in a high impact factor jornal. 

People from imperial will tell you they look after you and they will mediate between you and your supervisor. But the filling I had is that they will always take your supervisor' side as is him or her the one bringing money to the institution and who will stay after all.

review_title: A good place if you are young, single and want to make career in research (or already have a career))
pros: World-leading research, lots of interesting projects, quite a lot of them are from industry (so it's not THAT detached from real life). Staff and students are friendly and helpful and when they are not there is a very good support scheme from the uni to setlle such problems. Good pension scheme, own sports centre with the gym and swimming pool (though often packed with students), lots of extracurricular activities such as clubs and sports sections. Own nursery (though not free). Free unlimited travel insurance cover (if travel on Colege business). Can keep flexible hours (work from home sometimes or arrive later/leave earlier if needed).
cons: Very bad work-life balance. As other reviewers said, expectations are very high and work over weekends and around the clock is a norm here. Mentions of bad working conditions in some departments are also true (rooms are badly lit, stuffy, tiny, overcrowded. Not all of them of course, depends on the building). Salaries are small for London (and for this workload)

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Access to high quality infrastructure and resources, the cache of working for a "top" institution.
cons:
A management culture that prefers to suppress complaints rather than investigate them, and is happy to let bullies thrive as long as they are "productive". For all their kind words, if you go to them with a complaint management will work behind the scenes to make sure nothing happens - a typical tactic is to wait so long that your legal options have been timed out. Academic management have an excuse for being useless - they aren't trained in management. But Human Resources have no excuse. They know exactly what they are doing. Some of them are malicious and seem to take pleasure in the pain they cause.

This is an institution who has an employment lawyer from one of the most expensive legal firms in the country (the Queen's solicitors) on retainer, working on site one day a week. And they make full use of them. The lawyer isn't there to help Imperial stick to the law. They are there to help them get away with flouting it.

review_title: Relatively happy, easy-going and interesting workplace
pros: Great location (South Kensington) with beautiful surroundings (Hyde Park, Royal Albert Hall, museums, etc); prestigious reputation; public sector benefits (good pension, sick pay, extra leave on top of your annual leave when college is closed for Easter, Christmas, etc); relatively stable job market (security); access to library, student catering outlets and the gym/swimming pool; fairly easy-going office culture; good training opportunities; good support for those with long-term health issues and/or disabilities; highest salary (for my role) compared to other London universities.
cons: The College can be a little old fashioned and stuck in its ways at times. No opportunity for flexible working in my (student-facing) department. Some of the buildings/facilities are stuck in the 1960s (particularly administrative departments). No air conditioning in my building (which is a furnace in the summer!) Once you've reached the highest pay level within your role you are more or less stuck on that salary forever, unless you leave.

pros: There are many good colleagues across sciences and it is a prestigious university (if you like that kind of thing).
cons:
It's a very target focused environment, with a survival of the fittest attitude. This is not conducive to happiness of employees or actually good science. 
Management are very explicit about it not being a charity and they consequently feel they owe staff nothing. There is a frequent analogy with a market and faculty are stall holders who have to pay rent through grant income. Or analogy with a bank, and they make a loan to you (when you start) that you then have to pay back (through grant income). 
I don't know of other academic institutions in the UK where this is made that explicit.
Administration and high-level management are very very wasteful, with prestige projects that lose money, which then have to be paid for by increasing grant income from faculty. They are also having a huge building project, that again has to be 
These problems are particularly bad in the Faculty of Medicine.
Another problem is that there is no career advancement mechanism in the Faculty of Medicine to move from post-doc to lecturer etc.

review_title: Great staff benefits & culture, but very stressful sometimes and a bit disorganised
job_title: Human Resources Generalist Assistant in London, England
pros:
* Frequent CPD days - with a strong focus on helping you to pursue your own career development 
* Plenty of social events including Summer and Christmas party  (both free including food and drink!)
* Great staff benefits (especially through Perks@Work - 55% discount for the cinema :-)
* Amazing staff in the HR department and across the College in general
* Fantastic flexibility; working from home, hot desking at different campuses, compressed and variable hours to suit personal circumstances  
* Annual leave and days that the College is closed (such as nearly 2 weeks off at Christmas) amounts to 39 or 40 days including bank holidays
cons:
* So many staff (8,000 across the College) that the workload is often crazy in relation to the number of HR staff managing these queries/cases
* Poor communication when changes and processes are occurring; often drip fed information or you discover changes through speaking to your peers.

pros:
- It's your own project and depending on your supervisor, you generally have a lot of say with regards to direction. It's nice to have that level of autonomy.
- You get a lot of time to focus on your problem alongside some of the brightest academic minds in the world, in terms of both supporting staff and friends.
- It's such a long programme that you have some time to think about what you want to do next in your life, in theory anyway.
cons:
- Work is very individual, but most people know that going into a PhD.
- There's a lot of uncertainty with research, it's difficult to plan as determining how long things will take isn't simple.
- It's a long commitment to a single project, persistence is required.
- Imperial is probably the most expensive university in the country in terms of living costs. It'll be a stretch financially, especially as all of your London friends who are working will have much larger disposable incomes.

pros:
-Great development opportunity with generally good support. 
- Exciting work which you mainly get to set yourself. Good autonomy. 
- You get as much out of it as you put in
- Enjoyable office environment
- Get to work with very impressive people on the Trustee Board and in College Leadership
- Good internal recognition (although not comp!) for achievement
cons:
- Students mostly don't understand your job and it can often be a thankless task from the very people you are trying to serve
- Student politics
- Fairly high turnover of staff makes it difficult to have stability, although new members of staff have been excellent in role so far.
- At times have been unsupported by senior management including on major projects. Lack of resources that can be deployed on projects of strategic importance.
- Pace of change is faster than College, but overall is not as agile as it needs to be. Would recommend flattening management structure. 
- Needs a more entrepreneurial attitude in order to maintain growth in services, although this is improving.

review_title: Nice place to work at, except for usual academia 'mafia'
pros:
Very good university, generally nice environment. 

Although work load is usually high and you get to work long hours, you have great flexibility (you can work at whatever time you want, as long as you deliver and publish).

Great location.

Bike, shower and gym facilities available.
cons:
Long working hours in spite of flexible hours, hard to keep work/life balance.

As is common in academia, senior professors, even at top universities, have often lost track of research and end up delegating lots of their own work to their research assistants (overloading us, but usually getting the credit and the payment for it).

As is also common in academia, permanent lecturing positions are rare (you need to wait for someone to retire or die...). Research assistant's contracts are project-based, which means you have little stability.

While the salary is not bad, it is still not enough to have a fully comfortable life in central London (with this salary you most likely need to share a flat or so).

pros: - Fast Paced, very intensive and stimulating
cons: - Little time for a good social life, significant level of workload

review_title: Research directorate post: challenges and opportunities, in equal measures
job_title: Research Manager in South Kensington, England
pros: A lot of opportunities in research management. Generally, staff are trying to help and are supportive on daily basis, and vast majority are competent. General drive to make things better for researchers, so that they can focus on their work. Ideas are listened to and often are implemented, I certainly feel included and accountable, which is great for job satisfaction. Excellent career development opportunities, whether it's up or sideways.
cons: HR are dreadful, I never had to chase people for interview materials, no coherent process for new starters. Departmental structures vary, and with that, efficiency or getting tasks done. It's a vast university, and sometimes it's difficult to navigate- needs a solid structure with right people.

job_title: Working In the IT Department in London, England
pros: You are at the very edge of experience - always new, always changing, always learning.  You have access to the latest equipment, the latest software and some of the best brains in the world.
cons: Being a woman is very hard.  The culture is male and so the hours are long with family considerations ignored.  There appeared to be no understanding of the way a woman worked and how she achieved even though she did not think the same as the men.

pros:
Prestigious and big employer with excellent reputation for research
Good research facilities
Excellent opportunity for learning and development
Nice colleagues, diverse, open-minded and friendly 
Intellectually stimulating atmosphere, lots of things are going on
Flexible working hours
cons:
Lack of career progression, to move up you need to move out.
Loyalty to institution is not valued and is seen as a liability and inability
Bullying, intimidation and no job security. After 4 years as a postdoc you become permanent and your contract could be terminated with 1 month notice and barely 1 month pay. This creates a vial  atmosphere of dependency and bullying. Lots of nasty things are going behind the lab doors and the Institute doesn't care as long as PI brings in bags of money. It's all about money.
Sexism - if you are a woman your life is harder.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Imperial is a prestigious institution for academics - arguably the most prestigious one in London. Having the name on your CV is very helpful in terms of opening doors. Facilities are generally good to very good and a lot of money is being spent on upgrading the not so good ones. Generally speaking people here are at the top of their field.
cons: Your experience strongly depends on the lab you are in - unfortunately academics are promoted based on research prowess rather than management skill so there are some truly awful managers here. Awful means failure to acknowledge achievements / extra effort and sometimes pressure to work ridiculous hours. Time off is some times an issue as some PIs do not respect it.

review_title: Highly motivatined and ambitious University, however sometimes invest in the superficial over the basics
job_title: Researcher, PhD Candidate in South Kensington, England
pros:
- Surrounded by motivated, intelligent, people
- Fantastic location
- Freedom (PhD supervisor dependent!)
cons:
- Mechanical engineering building suffers from poor maintenance, constant plumbing issues, lift problem, toilet leaks, which are frustrating day-to-day and embarrassing when showing visitors around.
- Tendency to prioritise investment in the superficial (new signage, screens, facades etc.) whilst neglecting basic functions i.e. running cost-saving programme on food outlets leading to decreased quality.

review_title: I had the best job, worked with wonderful people and learnt to value the contribution science makes to society.
job_title: Senior Compliance Specialist in South Kensington, England
pros: Got to meet and collaborate with inspirational people, the work was rewarding and well paid, increases your confidence in your skills and abilities. Plenty of people to engage with re: setting priorities and helping in delivery.
cons: Poor leadership, weak management, a hostile, competitive, fearful environment.  Cronyism is rife, individuals are promoted for longevity and for being obsequious and obedient and supporting those with power and influence.  Refusal to acknowledge and address blatant discrimination and harassment, where HR are tasked with supporting bad practice and colluding in covering up misconduct and breaches of policy and processes.

review_title: Valuable learning experience but extremely frustrating.
pros:
Excellent resources in terms of equipment. The technical staff and kit in the workshops is of the highest quality. The experience and knowledge of the academic staff is second to none.

This gives a great environment to carry out high level research, but only for the truly independent scientist.

Oh, and a great mix of people.
cons:
Central admin is absolutely useless. They cannot be trusted to do their job in a timely manner and it ends up being your responsibility that things are carried through. They frequently act as if the research staff is in fact the support staff.

Promotion within the research staff is based on academic prowess (ability to acquire grant money). However, the academics are then required to become managers of growing teams. They lack experience or training for this task. This results in poor hire choices, muddled project objectives and wasted talent.

pros:
some great people stand out
good opportunities for networking/making contacts
fantastic staff development team and postdoc support unit also excellent
Great equalities team doing their best in very difficult environment
cons:
some parts of the College have toxic culture and poor employment practices
culture of cuthroat competition - sink or swim in some departments
practical/financial research support is given only to favoured "stars"
some bad apples seem to be supported and their bad behaviour is condoned - HR is shocking in these cases

pros: It is a good institution, and your colleagues are very intelligent.  The maths department has many world famous researchers, and the applied mathematicians are very forward looking (i.e. un afraid of new and emerging fields).
cons: The pay is too low in comparison with the price of housing.  The offices are very cramped.  The math department in particular is overly clique-ish, and this discourages cross pollination of ideas.  However, perhaps this last point is a criticism that could be made of maths as a field.  The biggest criticism is probably one I would expect the professors to make.  There is way too much emphasis on securing grants, and this really disrupted my supervisor's ability to focus on his actual research.

review_title: Postdoctoral position at Imperial College London
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Excellent academic atmosphere, quite easy to connect world-leading scientists. Also, London is a international city. even though the Brexit significantly affects people who are working in this city, but it is still worthwhile to give yourself a shot. Sometimes bad timing could the best timing.
cons:
Typical U.K. problems. British guys not only kill life for food, but also takes their flavor away. Chicken tikka masala probably is the best food that you can afford. Others are either too expansive or too disgusting, sometimes you can find stuffs with both in supermarket. 

Additionally, the underground (subway/metro) system in London is old. Not terrible but too old, which means, in certain station, you might carry a 20kgs luggage without any lift or escalator. That will makes your hands sour in a few days.

Last but not least, rental price in London, you know what I mean.

pros: Exciting and diverse organisation with world class research and a mission it has been a privilege to be part of.
cons: Relatively recent attempts to make college more businesslike (not in itself a bad thing in any way) have led to hiring -  in the kindest possible way the rejects of industry who aren’t good business people nor are they knowledgable and experienced in this sector.  In the private sector this would result in clear separation of winning and losing ideas and survival of only the fittest firms. In the public sector despite ongoing marketisation of education this effect is much slower and the result is an extremely costly vanity project (or a series of them). This is very sad for those of us watching a once great organisation flounder despite what was almost certainly good intentions originally.

review_title: Not ideal for medical research students
pros:
Location!
Great seminars/lectures organised by university
Networking events
cons: Unfortunately your development as researcher depend on your luck of supervisor. There is no consistency between the groups and there are some really bad ones, which seem on the outside as the lab with an expert leader. In reality you are left on your own, with no support/feedback, no opportunities. You have to do everything yourself and there is no point in asking graduate school for help as you will be just ignored.

pros: Very good place to work, good initial career & pay progression.  How good the employee experience is depends very much on the employee's line manager.  A great line manager makes working here really great. Very good flexible work arrangements for many different job categories.  Good pay in comparison to other public sector organisations.  A generally progressive environment, that is exciting to work in.
cons: Career and pay progression difficult beyond a certain mid management level. Not always transparent processes, some favouritism, some staff progress faster/better than others due to unequal values placed on different types of work or on line managers' degree of influence. Some line managers are very driven, on the edge of being in the "bully" classification.

review_title: Newly appointed lecturer at Imperial – thrown in a pool full of sharks when you can barely swim
pros: Status and salary. Imperial is a good brand name which gives you immediate status in the academic/research world. It also pays better wages and productivity premiums (e.g. for bringing big grants) compared to most British universities.
cons:
Tremendously competitive environment, entirely focused on results, being the student evaluation for teaching or the research funding. Very strict metrics evaluate staff performances. No support or internal collaboration. Tyrannic head of Department, constantly threatening under-performing staff out of his Department and stealing research ideas from younger member of staff. Servile senior members of staff mirroring Head's attitude of being a shark of research spaces and facilities and uncollaborative/hostile with new comers. 
To be avoided by newly appointed research lecturers unless they start supported by a substantial grant which takes the pressure off them for a year or so.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Kensington, England
pros: Full of very intelligent, interesting and interested people. Loads of very interesting stuff going on on campus. Great 'CPD' and career support, plus access to an amazing gym (much quieter when undergraduate students aren't around, but there was dedicated staff time on Tuesdays and Thursdays).
cons: South Kensington is beautiful, but it's in, and surrounded by, areas with very expensive accommodation costs. I commuted by bike (lots of places to lock your bike and plenty of 'city bike' provision) from Battersea where there's lots of affordable ex council accommodation.

review_title: A highly demanding environment that works only for the best people
pros: A top-ranked institution - makes it easier to attract good PhD students and postdocs, as well as to obtain external funding. Gets visited regularly by world leading scientists as guest speakers.
cons:
Not a friendly environment for people of average or below-average talent or ambition.

London is a very expensive places to live - and salary levels do not fully compensate for that, making you poorer than in the same kind of job at universities outside London (including Oxford and Cambridge).

pros: Lots of smart people and interesting things happening, good location.
cons: It's a big university, practically a big corporation disguised as an educational institute, and is thus very impersonal with you. Despite lots of big talk about life-balance, appropriate rewards and mental health, salaries are static and pressure is high. There's little chance of advancing inside, and the college is becoming increasingly dominated by Big Name professors and staff, lording it over the pool of people who actually do the work. Bad behaviour by higher staff is punished with a wristslap. But this is becoming typical of the top tier universities and I see little chance of it changing. I recommend any worker at ICL keep in mind what's in it for them and work towards that aim.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in South Kensington, England
pros: Give food in meetings and when they make you work long inhumane hours.
cons:
-Very long hours. If you don't you will be looked down on.
-Allergy and Immunology lab is the worst to work in, a lot of pressure of work. You would prosper better in other labs.
-You will not be able to work on your own given project
-The first authorship in this lab usually is very favourable as you are required to work in a team. Even if you do most of the work, it's very likely that someone else would get acknowledged. The PI of the lab works as a post-doc and treats post-docs as technicians. The professor is clueless about the lab as his eyes and ears are the PI. 
-Be very careful when you join this lab as the references may not help you in your next role.

review_title: Great people but authoratative and old style waterfall management need to upgrade methods
pros: Diverse people and students, lots of energy and facilities. except at Hammersmith - next to the jail but other campuses are great, gyms, clubs, cafe's, restaurants and good working experience.  Mostly flexible depends on manager.
cons:
All depends on your department and line manager.
Worked at South Kensington and loved the atmosphere although buildings older the campus includes lots of facilities and recreation but Hammersmith there are no facilities and the new buildings are full of tiny desks and open office - lacking any privacy.

pros:
- Very friendly, cooperative environment in the lower-ranks  within my department.
- Lots of opportunities to attend interesting talks provided by the college
- Great career service (one of the best I have encountered compared to other universities in London)
- Prestige of a degree from this uni
- Great sport facilities and catering if you are based in the main campus (South kensington)
cons:
- an admin-heavy university: sometimes might hinder a lot of research activities
- cruel progression system: heavily focuses on scores on grants and publications, does not often allow enough time for permanent staffs to produce great research work. 
- scattered research campuses for medical researches: difficult to collaborate nor attend activities in the main campus if you are in other campuses.
- there are often quite a lot of politics in the senior ranks

review_title: An important opportunity to expand and connect.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in London, England
pros: Networking opportunities with peers from within the organisation and from other similar organisations internationally, entrepreneurs and associated groups, start-ups, and with the largest corporations in Europe. Significant free time and flexibility in work time and location. Freedom to pursue own projects and set own agenda. Freedom to establish research groups without interference from senior management. Located in central London.
cons: Almost all funded projects involve severe amounts of bureaucracy and personal politics between senior staff. Governmentally-funded projects are particularly nasty to obtain and manage. Overall tendency for staff to form cliques and work on projects only within their clique. Many instances of senior staff to delay project with the objective of obtaining extended periods of funding.

pros: Imperial College truly has amazing facilities and a wide variety of very helpful principal investigators.  Specifically, the film facility and FACS services are manned by a few technicians with a world of experience in the technologies.
cons: When undergraduate students return in the fall, the dynamic of the university completely changes and drives the researchers back into their offices.  While there are several campuses, the South Kensington campus is the most well-located, but it also has the least space for collaborative discussion.

review_title: High energy, with some high pressure
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros:
People are great.
Everyone shares a common goal in science research. It can be very altruistic.
Projects and opportunities are good.
Wide range of support available.
cons:
Academia. Its no fault of the University. Academia is just awful if you want a stable income.
Can be very high pressure. Only those who are both gifted and sufficiently driven can really enjoy the experience to the full.

pros: Saying the right things about inclusion, bullying etc. Work with brilliant minds, really tests your own horsepower. You can work on stuff that really changes the world. Very flexible working conditions if you get the right manager.
cons: Don't anyways do what they preach! Leadership seem focused on "profit" and not what makes a happy working environment. Research prowess rewarded greater than teaching. Mysoginistic and bullying colleagues seem to thrive but recent "awareness training" needs to be institutionalised. Poor wages/benefits compared to peers and having to live in London.... Expensive

review_title: A nice place to do research.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros:
The good reputation of the institution. State of the art equipment and research facilities. Posibilities to network and collaborate with other very capable scientists. A lot of good seminars and conferences with very high profile speakers happening on campus... 

However what most pleasantly surprised me from Imperial College London compared to other universities where I have worked was the huge catalog of staff development courses and that you are entitled to take 10 days per year to attend this courses. They include a lot of transferable skills as: negotiation, proyect management, introduction to intellectual property, teaching skills... even first aid courses.
cons: Like working in any other academic place, the salary is lower than in the private sector.

review_title: Take the opportunity to work at Imperial College
pros:
Imperial teaches you - you have plenty of opportunities to get involved in cross departmental projects, if you are willing and you will learn from them.  If you are not an academic, get involved in some of the academic projects too - turn up and listen to guest lectures - the opportunities to learn are endless
Supportive staff and colleagues, generous leave and flexible working arrangements in some parts of the university are also great pros.
cons:
Poor strategic direction within some departments gets very frustrating.  Seems to be more of a problem with the business school than other units.
Can get blinkered - you end up focusing on a niche and then its hard to move into other areas

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in South Kensington, England
pros:
• Postdoc Development Centre – the first of its kind in UK universities - supports personal and professional development opportunities for postdocs and fellows.
• Working at top world class scientists and engineers at the forefront of research.
• Prestige – Imperial College is consistently one of the top universities in the world.
cons:
• Minor (general problem in London): the South Kensington Campus is in a very expensive part of London - thus, it is very expensive to live nearby work. Alternatively, one needs to have a long commute to work to live at a more affordable area in London. 
• Minor (general issue of academia):  lack of opportunities to stay doing research as a senior scientist and not being an independent principle investigator.

review_title: Overall, a good place to work, but not without failings.
pros: As an academic institution, Imperial does understand the benefits of having well-trained staff. Its own Staff Development Unit is very able and deals well with soft skill development. For development in other areas, managers will often positively consider external training and association with external agencies to be a benefit.
cons: Management is very spotty. Senior management are too far removed from what is going on at both the "chalkface" dealing with students, and also with those in departments making the College actually work. Middle management ranges from abysmal to very good -- I've had experience of both.

review_title: Miserable Researcher at top rated Imperial College
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: The students are some of the best.
cons:
Line manager (Professor/ reader) of Research Associate (RA) are generally not very transparent about the contract and their career progress. Although research associates are college employee but unfortunately they are treated only as a staff employed by a particular academic almost similar status as PhD student or even worse.  Essentially research staffs in Imperial College are miserable with no proper support.
Line manager of RA never helps to develop their research staff career. In contrary professors usually force to work on project denying to write a reference. In research staff contract says light teaching but usually keep their research staff away from any teaching responsibility and kill their teaching career. Basically research staffs in Imperial College are miserable with no proper support.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: The hours are flexible depending on your lab supervisor. It is an intellectually stimulating environment where you will be surrounded by intelligent colleagues who take part in some fantastic research
cons: The professors are at war with each other due to excessive pressure to perform from the Imperial administrators. Lab collaboration within Imperial is currently very loosely associated with the word collaboration

review_title: Great place to conduct postgraduate research
job_title: PhD Researcher in South Kensington, England
pros:
Great place to continue academic studies and conduct research.
Work-life balance can be an issue, since your time is completely flexible it is essential to get good at time management.  
The facilities are excellent and there is a lot of support from the academic staff and lecturers.
cons: It is a competitive environment so can become overwhelming. Most of the work is individual so if you run into a problem you have to rely largely on yourself to resolve it. Career progression is slow.

review_title: Full of fantastic people, but also a lot of paper-pushers
pros:
- Some of the brightest minds around: staff, students
- Lots of staff (academic and support) who really care about their job and do 90% of the work
cons:
- Too many managers, bloated teams and old fashioned practices that aren't efficient
- Large organisation; everything works slowly, and there is a constant power-grab battle from top-down

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Imperial College has a development team and centre just for post-docs, fairly unique!  Good number of holidays, and flexible working hours.  Research done at college is at a high level, reasonably friendly co-workers.
cons: Main site is in South Kensington, very expensive to live there.  Has additional sites all over London, which can make meeting with collaborators take a while to do (40 - 60 min commute between the 2 sites I regularly work between).  In terms of paperwork and admin, health and safety stuff is slightly worse than other UK universities I've worked at.

pros: have a short ride on the Imperial College name. Make use of good and large range of scientific Journals without paying a subscription
cons: Commute long distances or rent a hole in the wall to live in at exorbitant prices. Work in confined spaces moving your equipment often so others can use your space. Share noisy office space. Work long hours to make up for lost time because equipment or space was being used by others. Never take your full entitlement of leave because you are trying to make up for lost time.

review_title: Master thesis project student - department of computing
pros: Lots of freedom : they let me choose my own self-proposed topic, but I could also have chosen between more than a hundred supervisor-proposed projects.
cons: Too much freedom : I couldn't see my supervisor as often as I would have liked. It was okay for me because I was building the project from scratch anyway, but for a supervisor-proposed project, this could have interfered with the quality of the work.

pros: Money, theres lots of it around, this doesn't necessarily mean opportunity though. Well located if you can afford it. Good reputation (for some reason).
cons:
Expensive place to live. 
Unless you are from a rich family, you will struggle to get by in London. 
Lots of rich students around.
No student culture. Low levels of student satisfaction, especially in the post-graduate world. 
Completely integrated with the corporate world, lots of oil, pharma and agrochemical influence. Great if you want to work in industry, but if you want to work with inspiring alternative people, go elsewhere. 
Have not known anyone to have loved their time at Imperial. You have to have a certain kind of mindset to work there. It's unforgiving and alienating, cold and uninspiring.

review_title: A bigger place than many people imagine somewhat obsessed with climbing league tables.
pros: The opportunity to interact with some of the brightest people on the planet in one of the most exclusive parts of London.
cons: Having to deal with some of the largest egos on the planet and finding that the culture is not collaborative but often destructively competitive.

review_title: Good place to work especially for people with children.
pros: Imperial College strives to be inclusive education and offers flexible working hours for some knowledge based unmanned positions.  Decent benefits and time off with support for continuous development.  Located in a nice part of town.
cons: Very slow decision making from senior management, sometimes a result of paralysis from analysis.  Although there have been efforts to br more inclusive at ground level there are still biases which can be very subtle on the surface whilst still being undermining.

pros: Imperial College has a huge range of career advisors, and many multi-disciplinary networking events, all year round. In addition it is the heart of a few enterprise incubators of Tech city of London, as such, students looking for industrial placements from a degree in Imperial College should feel right at home.
cons: The typical cons involved with living in London, the transport service is in shambles when you need it. Imperial tries to help by introducing the electric car scheme to its member of staffs but the adoption is slow.

review_title: Research at the Civil Engineering Department
pros: Imperial College London offers a unique opportunity for young researchers who are eager to work with the best people in the field and want to experience life in the never-stopping London. Exposure to groundbreaking science is guaranteed. You will feel the responsibility and the benefit of your research being produced in such a prestigious university: the scientific community tends to respect and pay attention to the work produced in Imperial and will seek collaboration and/or cite your research with more assiduity.
cons: The facilities are not state-of-the-art and are space constrained but then again the Campus is in one of the most expensive streets in the world.

pros: Working at Imperial College has been overall a good experience. It is a great university and gives you lots of opportunities. I had the opportunity to learn from great scientists and meet fantastic people! Plus Imperial is a great name on your CV and there are plenty of career advice to make the most of..
cons: However..  the name and the rating of this university is strictly related to some specific departments (e.g. engineering or chemistry) so don't expect that any place you'll go work will be worthy of the 5th worldwide university or 3rd UK university because it won't.. and quality of research is really poor in some groups.

pros: Imperial offers opportunities to work with very bright people. The job satisfaction is great. There are many opportunities to collaborate with other people, get training on variety of career development issues. In addition terms and conditions of typical employment contract are excellent.
cons: There are no big downsides of working at Imperial College. Some people may consider working in London as a negative point but it can also be seen as a positive point.

review_title: Intimidating managers and bullying  by seniors.
pros: The team on the actual floor is working hard. We are supposed to and we like to do so.
cons:
Bullying by managers and intimidation by involving other staff and setting people up against each other. Creating a untrustworthy environment towards Management! A certain Manager doesn't work as confidential as work in NHS is supposed to be.  
On top of this all Band 2 for being a healthcare assistant is also not ok. The amount of work we put into this trust....
And not getting appreciation financially.

review_title: Top science in a pretty toxic environment
pros:
Surrounded by excellent science. 
The facilities are excellent.
Excellent catering on the South Kensington campus in the SCR.
Excellent facilities and support for improving foreign language skills. 
Excellent sports facilities at South Kensington, including a swimming pool.
London location makes it easy to collaborate with institutions such as UCL, King's, LSE etc, and also to access their libraries with the SCONUL card. 
IT, library facilities all worked very well.
Central university support for PhD students to attend conferences. 
Sensible focus on developing transferable skills for PhD.
My department encouraged all PhD students to have a mentor, and this was very helpful.
cons:
Bureaucracy extremely inflexible, driven by central desire to save costs in a way that often felt counter-productive (such as common scenario of two members of PhD/research staff attempting to books tickets through a complex system raising purchase orders, which disrupted a couple of hours all-in-all, in order to save fairly minimal administrative costs generated by expenses forms. Such systems generated tensions between academic/research and professional staff, which is unfortunate.
Intensely competitive, often dog-eat-dog environment. It seemed to me relatively frequent to come into contact with aggressive, unfriendly or bullying academics compared to other universities of equivalent stature. 
One supervisor who completely neglected student after self-funded student (cancelling meetings at the last minute or just not turning up, failing to read papers/chapters sent to him), who then would eventually drop out (I counted around 10 dropping out during my three years), was never sanctioned in any way. The management told me it was a case of buyer beware. 
Many people in my department were unhappy. There was very little feeling of a department community.
Central library at South Kensington a little noisy, even in silent zones.

pros: I am a PhD student in the department of Aeronautical Engineering. After a few international conferences and by comparing the work carried on in my department with that of other institutions I can quite confidently say that the quality of the research at Imperial is outstanding. The academics are world class. The environment is challenging and stimulating and there is plenty of opportunities to learn (seminars and workshops), grow (good supervision and student support) and enjoy yourself (very active student union).
cons: Facilities are not always top notch and the technical staff could be improved. Also, paperwork and health and safety procedures sometimes are excessive!

review_title: Imperial great for researchers, London isn't.
pros:
Reputation of the university 
Good access to equipment
Receives a lot of research money
Department of Medicine supports fellowship applications
Plenty of coffee shops
cons:
Central London expensive to live in and so modest Postdoc salary mostly spent on rent
Accommodation in central london not great
Not enough Imperial staff accommodation
Competitive atmosphere favours those who focus on personal interests ahead of the group
Forced to engage in essesive public engagement that is detrimental to your work 
Very few fellows gain long term employment opportunities

review_title: Good institution to perform academic research in Physics.
pros: Intelligent people with considerable expertise,  many being leaders in their fields. As universities go, Imperial College is well-funded by research grants and has some equipment that can almost compete with national lab scale facilities.
cons:
There is a relatively common trait of academic staff to not value the time of research students; where a relatively inexpensive professional solution could be found, certain academics are very happy for a student to spend months working on unpublishable tasks.

Difficult to get a permanent post, so job security is generally poor as well as remuneration not being particularly good.

job_title: Former Student/Research Analyst in South Kensington, England
pros: I throughly enjoyed my time at Imperial. The people were absolutely fantastic and incredibly supportive. I also found the food in the h-bar as delicious.
cons: Perhaps they should remove the tents from the queens lawn post-graduation in Oct a lot sooner. I would also appreciate if they could serve lays or hula hoops in their connivence stores on campus. Those are most definitely my favourite crisps.

pros:
Great academics, motivational super, great people to work with. Life is what you make of it. What you get is the snob factor great equipment lots to learn and a reputation to set you up for life. Network with really great people
You don't need to look for funding your super has done all that. Your super just needs a new pain in the neck!
cons: Space gets tight. Pressure is high to achieve . Some of my fellow phd era were far to intelligent for their own good

review_title: Great place to study and work at
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: As a researcher at Imperial you have the opportunity to work and collaborate with very talented colleagues in a stimulating environment. Very good training programs and courses. Flexible working hours.
cons: Professors and PI's often lack very basic management and leadership skills. Working conditions and opportunities often varies a lot between different labs.

review_title: Review of research project at Imperial College London
pros: Good to experience a working environment during the duration of studies. Interesting research opportunities and plenty of opportunities to network with staff which opens doors to many other research opportunities in all departments around college.
cons: Long work hours and the pay was average. Not ideal location for accommodation in central London. Expensive to get there. Work environment not ideal with students around computer labs pretty much every day.

review_title: Money is king, staff wellbeing not so much
job_title: Post Doctoral Research Associate in South Kensington, England
pros: Pays higher than most other universities, especially Business School.
cons: So much depends on the individual supervisor but the system does not seem to deal proactively/preventatively with potential for boundaries to be crossed and bullying staff (it may react effectively sometimes though what I have seen does not support that). Funding income is king. Researchers kept too busy to focus on own career development. Does not support staff standing up to external research partners when needed.

review_title: Busy, can be cut-throat, old systems, but easy to upgrade position/salary if you're smart
job_title: Finance Officer in South Kensington, England
pros: Easy to increase your grade/salary and responsibility if you're intelligent and personable. Plenty of young people in positions of responsibility.
cons: Can be very money focused, work tempo is always high and there aren't many non-busy periods. Full of egos - both academic and administrative. Administrative/finance systems are dated and are definitely not on par with the quality of the research.

job_title: Fire Safety Manager in London, England
pros: Most  of the best time do the work for fire safety section cold season in our Bangladesh .
cons: downside at first must be perfect completed  fire related work . After day by day we are perfect completed upside to the fire safety related work .

pros: Great links with industry and most of teaching staff are experts in their fields, having done research in top universities around the world or worked for the most successful companies in the industry. Very international alumni as well. South Kensington is a very privileged location in the center of London with great transport links.
cons: Very fast paced and busy environment. This includes many interesting events happening on campus regularly which may overlap. Time management and prioritisation is key otherwise the experience can be overwhelming.

review_title: Great place to work, but high stress
pros: I've enjoyed working at Imperial because of excellent colleagues (very smart, generous with their time, friendly), good facilities which are constantly being upgrade, and a wide selection of interesting topics to work on.
cons: The biggest downside is the central London location -- it's very expensive to live nearby.  But also it can be a high stress environment.  There are simply not enough hours in the day to do what's expected and that means things routinely spill over into evenings and weekends.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Imperial does a lot for the professional development of its employees. It's a very good University with really good colleagues.
cons: As usual in many academic fields: Too many Post Docs, too few more stable career options.

pros:
Imperial’s commercial arm uses campus spaces to run high profile external and internal events.
Opportunities to work on important AGMs, dignitary visits, science fairs etc.
Office and operations teams are full of good, friendly people.
Managers are do-ers who get involved with the hands on running of an event.
cons: The department invests in good AV equipment but some of the spaces (ie. Great Hall) were dated, with tired infrastructure, when I was there.

pros: A fantastic place to work, great colleagues, great students, great support staff, brilliant leadership, beautiful campus, one of best universities in the world
cons: There are now downsides that immediately spring to mind, and after quite a bit of thought and reflection it is very difficult to say that there are any cons to being part of imperial college london

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: The pay is good, as far as academia goes, and the administration is excellent. The quality of research is also (usually) good.
cons: The faculty are overworked and always under intense pressure to deliver funding and publications, sometimes at the expense of good quality research. That pressure is then, of course, shouldered by the more junior staff and PhD students.

review_title: Imperial College one of the better paying uni's in UK
pros: High-level research, great networking opportunities/professional contacts, friendly, helpful. Wages one of the highest for academic posts in London (linked to spine-points on a ladder, within pay bands). free £124 childcare voucher. Great flexibility with working hours or working from home.
cons: Wish they would have given the full £256 childcare voucher, and more opportunities to get bonuses. Pay-scale linked to ladder of spine-points so not much movement to go up. Slow and bureaucratic administrative/HR processes (lots of form filling and waiting for paperwork to go through)

review_title: Disappointing experience, but hopefully beneficial careerwise.
pros: Extra pay for teaching jobs. Personal development seminars. Location in South Kensington is great. Bike and shower facilities are available. Flexible work hours.
cons: Very isolated work. Little teamwork on the job. Little infrastructure to carry out the tasks. Very bad professional services in some areas (virtually non-existing IT department). Often mishaps with finances which can result into two months without pay.

job_title: PhD Student At Imperial College London in London, England
pros:
Full of talented researchers with real enthusiasm for their work. 
Interdisciplinary collaborations encouraged and facilitated between engineering and medical sciences.
Personal and professional development encouraged for employees at all stages in their career
cons:
Sharing of resources can be difficult at times with inconsistent levels of central organisation of specialised equipment or expertise.
Technical support often hard to find due to emphasis on hiring research and academic staff as opposed to technical staff.

review_title: Pretty decent as places for your PhD go
pros:
- ample funding available for PhD students in most groups
- pretty well-equipped core facilities
- make an effort to provide researchers with translatable skills
- great location
cons: Well, it's academia... Imperial is a good place to do your PhD, but ultimately that experience is never going to be very pleasant, no matter where you are.

review_title: Good place to work, hard place to progress
pros:
Great work life balance with benefits such as:
- Subsided gym.
- Bike and travel card loans.
- Ability to buy additional holiday.
- Learning portal (Lynda.com).
- Great pension (golden handcuffs really).
- Competitive salary
cons:
In the area of central ICT it is very difficult to progress with few secondment/acting up roles being available.

It will also be difficult to leave due to the previously mentioned benifits

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Kensington, England
pros: Prestigious and very academically orientated - so your peers will also be of high standard which pushes you to work harder
cons: VERY ANTISOCIAL/ not a fun place to attend for uni. Even though I'm not the most sociable person in uni, I find that Imperial is less sociable compared to other universities.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Work at one of the best universities in the world with some of the greatest minds. Imperial has good laboratory facilities. There are opportunities for teaching and supervising undergraduate projects which adds diversity to the working on your research project.
cons: Central London location means salary doesn't stretch very far as living costs are high. Little job security as position is reliant on grant or industry funding.

pros:
You can work from home.
Intriguing environment.
You meet interesting people and you have the opportunity to attend any lecture in your department.
cons: I didn't find any negatives yet. I am just inserting random words to reach the word limit. My apologies for that.

job_title: Structural Biology Student in Chelsea, England
pros: As expected, facilities and research performed at Imperial are at a very high standard. There is a large amount of flexibility with topics I have been able to study within my course, though, this is highly dependent on the research group you are a part of.
cons: Select your project leader/supervisor wisely. I have been incredibly lucky and have had no problems with my supervisors, but if you dont get on with them from the start, it is unlikely to work in the long term, Ive heard many stories.

pros: There's usually a good amount of significant work that's given to you and you often learn quite a few new skills such as how to use new software, report writing etc. Most people are usually happy to help.
cons: Everyone's very busy so getting someone to give you their time can be a bit difficult. Furthermore in research often the tests or simulations can end up taking hours which can be very boring.

pros: Flexible working hours, nice and fruitful environment, plenty of equipment and support available to use
cons: Salary is low for he London area, refurbishment of labs has been badly executed - successive and ongoing issues in setting or installing experiments cause minor to severe delays

review_title: Great place to undertake PhD studies and to enjoy student life
pros: Great selection of students clubs and societies, as well as as access to courses from the Imperial College Business School. Great name to have on CV for most jobs.
cons: Being an institution focused on STEM courses, the diversity in interests (and gender) is not as great at some other universities. However, being in London, this does not affect you too much. Also, living near campus can be quite pricy!

pros:
Good people
Good location
Good dining 
Good qualifications
cons:
Bullying
Harassment 
Nepotism
Racism
Brushed under the carpet

review_title: A great place to develop your academic profile, collaborate and network with brilliant scientists
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in London, England
pros: Lab and office facilities are great. It has great scientists and interesting projects. It is generally well organised and welcome to changes and initiatives. It embraces diversity and promotes collaborations and interdisciplinary projects.
cons: Specific campuses feel more isolated and could have been improved with better catering and social events. More funding to PhDs or postdocs would be of great help for conference attendance and short extension of work.
The tuition fee of the imperial college is too high and the professors do not have a lot of time to take care of you. You have to be very self-motivate to achieve some thing.

pros: Depends on the department, but generally pleasant and supportive community, not much political power play at the department level compared to other top universities. Quite international and diverse place at least at the level of students and junior-middle academic staff.
cons: It feels that overall the college values its management and pr above teaching, research and key academic activities which are kind of taken for granted. As everyone in UK universities, level of bureaucracy is relatively high and keeps going up.

review_title: Faculty of Medicine - for Medics only
pros: Good salary, location, access to good students, recognised as highly (RAE) ranked, so it is easier to obtain grant funding
cons: Faculty of Medicine is run by medics for medics. PhD scientists are second class citizens. Bar is much higher for promotion.

pros: Friendly community.  Decent salary. You can learn a lot during your time there and it is quite enjoyable. Allowed to carry out independent work often.
cons: Hard work ethic required. Need to be able to cope with stressful situations. Difficult to manage social life around work life. Expensive area to live in.

pros: The pay is pretty decent, especially as not many people there work hard or are even qualified to do their jobs. Registry is particularly full of people who have been given promotions due to being friends with people instead of based on knowledge or merit.
cons: Ongoing projects that never end. Lack of leadership. Lack of accountability. Full of people who blag everything and know nothing. The people who make it out and find a decent job elsewhere are better off.

pros:
top university, very good atmosphere, lot of scientific activity

Salary was great, however that is related to the grant rather than the university. Most postdocs are paid ok, but not great since you are in London.
cons:
Space issues, you are working with several postdocs in a small rooms. Moreover we were all on grants of which they took a big overhead.

The most annoying thing however are the (in)famous toilet queues. They are however working on these issues

job_title: Research Associate in South Kensington, England
pros: Good location and good in university rankings. There are many good seminars and chances for networking. It also has good professional development facilities.
cons: Overcrowded environment, some problems with the experimental conditions. Living in London is very expensive. Seems to be a pressure for those working there to publish a lot.

review_title: Great place to work, salary a bit low.
pros: Brilliant colleagues, availability of library, good perks (£124 free childcare vouchers every month, pension scheme & life insurance, discount on courses for staff and their children.). Due to college size, it is easy to move to other positions internally and many interesting events.
cons: Salary is lower than in the private sector, especially for academics. Some administrative tasks are slow due to the size of the college.

pros: Great environment to work and there are always money available for reseseah purposes. Great support from experienced professors of the department and a well-structured MSc project in general.
cons: Could benefit from more young group leaders on the field. Marking should be quicker and not take that long. Lack of opportunities for students wishing to stay at the Departmenet of Surgery and Cancer for a PhD.

pros: Imperial has a good VPN service that allows you to connect from college machines from home.Talented people, great work environment, amazing experience, beautiful campus, location fantastic.
cons: salary could be higher given the  quality of research done. fantastic place to work but salary is not as good as other industry. But i guess its university.

pros: A lot of good and helpful colleagues, very friendly research environment. Quite close to different museums and Royal Albert Hall. The supervisors and administrators are very nice.
cons: It is quite far away from my accommodation.  The location of this university is too nice which makes the rent of the house close to the university is very expensive.

review_title: Horrific Experience at the Business School
pros:
Intelligent colleagues 
Good amount of Annual Leave (though realistically most people won't get to truly take this)
Some flexibility 
Some departments are better than others
cons:
Lack of transparency
Constant stress
"One rule for one person, another rule for another" 
Being asked to deliver more and more, and not being compensated or acknowledged 
Disinterested/passive managers who don't act on issues
Low morale among the majority not at senior management 
Casual racism and misogyny

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: For a postdoc, Imperial College is a great place to work. The location in central London is excellent. Lots of opportunities to benefit from world class experts or establish academic or industrial collaborations within the college / London / Oxbridge area.  The PFDC (postdoc and fellows development center) offers many helpful courses and services. Excellent career opportunities.
cons: Very high living costs (rent, transport)

review_title: Male-dominated Imperial College lacks support structure and promotes unhealthy working conditions
pros:
Free Counselling
Free Meditation

Very international. Met some interesting people there.
cons:
I had my worst time of my life at Imperial College. 
Bully groups, high pressure, working hours meant that I had no private life. 
Got depressed and burnt out. When I seeked for help, no opportunities to cut down the workload were offered. Instead I was asked to leave. 
Impossible attitude towards employees. 
Unrewarding and harsh environment. No support.  
This unsustainable culture will run Imperial College down. 

Hardly any core facilities, which makes it hard if you want to apply a plethora of techniques.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros:
- close to central London
- close to transport links
- good reputation
cons:
- no discipline in the group
- very poor communication due to no group meetings 
- Ph. D students shouting, swearing and having tantrums in the office 
- students constantly on mobile phones, shouting and texting all day
- no support, backup or proper help with methods, techniques, or when giving seminars
- no welcome on first day - just left to fend for oneself - not introduced to colleagues and no site tour

job_title: Marie Curie Fellow in London, England
pros:
Scientifically amazing and friendly working colleagues.
Lively surroundings in London provides good work-life balance.
cons:
Inefficient administration and central facilities
Culture that relies of health and safety to reduce work load
Administration that uses bureaucracy as an excuse to not work

review_title: Great place overall to study for a PhD
pros: Excellent equipment and other material resources. Good study environment with many experienced people. Very good opportunities for career development via available courses at Graduate school.
cons: Low salary (albeit tax free) compared to a PhD in other countries. Work-life balance is mostly dependent on supervisor leadership.

job_title: Student Financial Support in London, England
pros:
family friendly
flexible working
lovely campus
students are lovely 
variety of food in the canteens
short walk to tube station
cons:
management not open to change
depending which department you are a part of- majority of staff are lovely but the team i worked in had issues and high staff turnover as the managers were always micro managing and lacked respect and communication skills.

review_title: Great place to work although the pay is lousy
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros:
- Cutting edge research takes place there.
- Working with people at the top of the field.
- Very strong reputation.
cons: Salaries are low for post-docs.

review_title: Role involving lab management, teaching and research support.
pros:
- Well-equipped labs with some of the latest equipment
- Safety protocols taken seriously
- Generally relaxed working atmosphere except some busy term times
cons:
- need to submit timesheet recording the details time and activity regularly for approval by line manager (not necessarily a bad thing, but can be a nuisance)
- not one of the most well-paid jobs, considering that the post is based in London with high living expenses

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Good work environment, friendly and with necessary tools to produce great science! I recommend! good place to learn and development
cons: Usually research associate positions have limited contracts and progression gets to lecturer is difficult because there are less positions available. Imperial offers a range of different options that we can go into instead.

pros: Achieve world class research in growing scientific pole in west london. Excellent career development opportunities and very good career advice service.
cons: Size and scale of employer means it's easy to miss out on what's going on around you and, most importantly how to access all available resources.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Kensington, England
pros: Very interesting and varied work that is primarily technical with great opportunities for learning, writing papers, travel to conferences, extra consultancy work etc. Working with a lot of smart people so can be a very stimulating environment. Do a lot of work with industry, which is good exposure
cons: High stress environment, very difficult to get progress to lecturer from post-doc.  Timelines are always tight and seems that you are always over-stretched.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in London, England
pros: Absolutely everything that a PhD student requires. You will be well taken care of academically, loads of clubs/societies to involve in, and tons of chances to make connections with some of the best in their field. Absolutely thrilling experience.
cons: None except the fact that the academic pressure may be slightly higher some other colleges, but I think this is acceptable given the global reputation and ranking of Imperial.

pros:
I suffered from illness during my time at Imperial and both my immediate managers and the central college we very supportive in letting me take the time I needed to get better.

The pay is above average for the sector.
cons:
As with an university there's a lot of 'we're doing it because that's how we've always done it'.

Communication between the departments and central services are weak.

Not that mush chance for career progression.

review_title: Fantastic place if you are a male, white, STEM researcher
pros: Wonderful research staff; very supportive departmental level administrators; intellectually curious and open-minded environment; world leading research; very engaged students
cons: huge, slow, bureaucracy - too much red tape; real lack of gender, racial and religious diversity at the top - very white, european dominated culture which is not flexible to change

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Excellent facilities, all equipment needed for research is available somewhere on the college campus.  All groups willing to collaborate.
cons: Undergraduates take over the campus during term time. It's hard to meet people outside of your research group.  The campus itself being in South Kensington makes it difficult on academic pay to live close to work.  The tourists visiting the area slow down commuting times.

review_title: A great institutution that advances knowledge
job_title: PhD Student At Imperial College London in London, England
pros:
I have thoroughly enjoyed myself during my time at Imperial: great equipment, great support from supervisor, great environment (colleagues + office and lab spaces + location)
also London is an exceptional city to live in.
cons:
Accommodation cost is high.
PhD can be tough at times, it is not particular to this instituion.
high expectations

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros:
Top notch information system
The only UK university with a post-doctoral development centre
Excellent central facilities
Good holiday allowance
Good staff cantine
Located in a vibrant and appealing city
cons:
Long commute and expensive rents are the norm
Generally demanding senior management
The majority of supervisors treat Post-Docs akin lab rats
Few opportunities of promotion to lecturer

review_title: Good reputation not so great quality
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: All good things that come with a big University. Really focused on business and industry. Great opportunities to find a job after the PhD. Good reputation. Great location.
cons: Depends on the department but a typical student tells stories were of frustation. Bioengineering is not recommendable. As a postdoc things are slightly different since you get more freedom. Don't expect high impact publications. Not good for working in academia.

review_title: Amazing University with enormous potential and great opportunities for those who are willing to work hard
pros: Takes your understanding of the subject to a completely new level. Looks very good on your CV. Plenty of resources, support, and motivation for accomplishments.
cons: Very demanding. If you want to take your degree seriously and aim for a 1st or 2:1 you got to devote to it most of your time.

review_title: Easy to do one's job when health and safety, admin and technicians don't get on your way
job_title: Postgraduate Teaching Assistant in London, England
pros: Clever students and clever colleagues. Timetable is very reasonable. Flexible hours more or less. Interesting topics to teach or do labs about.
cons: Admin is slow and lengthy. Facilities are outdated. Salary is low and they take very long to pay occasional workers. Techinician's availability is precarious. Most of them are not very competent either.

review_title: pretty good research experience in Imperial College, good place for anyone who is after an academic career.
pros: good working environment, nice people around. the head of the department is very encouraging and fair. would recommend to anyone who is pursuing an academic career
cons: the large organization is low in making changes but this situation is hopefully to improve in the future with new young blood coming in. Tough competition

review_title: Very positive experience with very good, motivated colleagues!
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Challenging, stimulating, full of opportunities, dynamic environment, young people, good networking, good travelling, flexible, very flexible. overall very good place, great facilities!
cons: sometimes too slow to get things done, approved or purchased, some politics involved, quite long hours in some period of the years

job_title: Phd Student Researcher in London, England
pros: Flexible working; very good reputation and highly "bankable" experience in the future
cons: A highly embedded culture of protecting/putting under the rug bad management and staff interactions. highly competitive; lacks team-spirit and support of personal development opportunities. Supposedly trying to address these issues at the top level, let's see how it goes. Fingers crossed things will indeed change, there is so much wasted intellectual and collective talents there!

pros: Top uni, fantastic lecturer supports and reputation, job prospects are good
cons: Expensive uni fee, ethos gym are not free even it only costs Gbp 35 to sign up.  the international students pay 25,000 pounds a year with constant 500 pounds increase in every year.

pros: Relatively good salary and benefits, campus infrastructure, reputation
cons: too many egoistic, too competitive or even psychopathic-type people

pros: Imperial takes part in cutting edge research. The medical school and college have a large number of top scientists.  The college has a very strong reputation. Strong at translational research.
cons: Too much red tape. Like any large organisation it is slow to change course or adapt to change sometimes. Can be frustrating to get the necessary administrative support.

pros: Very stimulating academic environment; top-class academic institution provides great opportunities for collaborations both within the college and other organizations; great future career opportunities; the Dean and senior leadership are addressing issues with bullying and gender inequalities.
cons: Issues with bullying and gender inequality; difficulties with career progression and uncertain contracts on postdoc level

review_title: World class research university. Good to advance your academic career.
pros: Research here is world class. Very international and open. There are perks for employees. Many societies and activities that you can join after work. Excellent and cheap sport facilities. Wonderful central London location.
cons: Depending on your PI it can be stressful. People aim high which translates on working hard. Living near campus is very expensive.

pros: Excellent access to materials i.e. free use of the library, access to online journals. Excellent colleagues and a very supportive environment.
cons: My current pay is low as it is based on the grant obtained for the project. Travel can cost quite a lot if you are travelling through multiple zones underground but not working every single day.

pros: Dynamic environment, exception quality of staff (academic and professional), exciting projects, strong vision and identity, well respected organisation, Imperial supports staff and staff with families, promotes training. Just a good place to work, great name on the CV
cons: lack of space but this will be addressed soon as it is expanding

pros: Great place with great people! You know you are with some of the most exceptional minds of our world. People are open and willing to give you time to talk and bounce research ideas.
cons: It can be expensive to live in Central London but lovely nevertheless :) It is South Kensington after all!

review_title: PhD candidate with little help/advice outside of the lab
pros: World Class reputation, London-location allowing strong collaborations, world-leader in biomedical research
cons: No mentorship or assistance outside of the laboratory environment. Not all campuses are equal - money/resources/facility priority towards certain divisions

pros: Good flexible working hours and forty eight days annual leave. Ability to go to conferences and training courses and good administration support.
cons: it is very difficult to get promoted. there is no clear career progress plans within the organisation for research associates.

review_title: Back in the 80s -but maybe that's not such a bad thing
pros: Friendly environment with good employee benefits
cons: Paternalistic, masculine to the core.

pros: It got very high rankings, and you can enjoy the nice vibes in south kensington,London. Teaching staff are of high standards.
cons: Very stressful, and heavy workload. Everyone is going to the library after school, so you have to push your limits

review_title: Exciting academic environment with strong ties with the industry
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in London, England
pros: Reputable professors and academic staff, highly prestigious research groups funded by European projects as well as internal funds, friendly working environment and nice campus to work at.
