cons: Exaggerated bureaucracy in some processes and at times limitations on the acquisition of costly lab equipment.

pros: Good employee benefits and overall well paid compared to similar HE Institutes.
cons: Practice of employing acquaintances is rife. Procedure dictates all roles must be advertised, so to get around this they advertise, people make genuine and time consuming applications without having any genuine chance of getting a position.

review_title: Great for engineering, there are better for medicine
pros:
Work life balance is good
Good student support if you ask for it
Salary is better than others for a PhD
cons: Insane bureaucracy, little if any collaboration between departments means everyone wastes time repeating work that others may have already done.

review_title: World class research, expect low pay and long working hours for PhD students
job_title: Phd Student Researcher in London, England
pros:
Excellent international research
South kensington campus is an excellent place to work (museums, Hyde park, Albert Hall)
Lots of societies for students
Large number of PhD students
Grad school is very good
cons:
Expensive living conditions
Facilities for PhD students are limited (e.g no longer food at PhD bar)
Long working days
Low pay even with additional London weighting

pros: Imperial has a very friendly environment, with high flexibility on the work/life balance, and it is at the heart of london
cons: The salaries are really low for living in London (but it is higher than many other institutions),and unfortunately sometime  if you want to go up the ladder you have to deal with the high competition

pros: South Kensington location is very central and beautiful campus. I enjoyed working in a stimulating environment with cutting-edge research. There are many available scientific seminars, conferences, and talks free to attend for staff members.
cons: Campus are located quite far from each others which make it sometimes difficult to interact with colleagues working in similar field of research

pros: Great company growing institution - lots of opportunities to go on courses, lots of perks to be involved in committees as admin staff. Always a lot to do.
cons: Main structure at faculty level is fantastic but each department has different structure and management. Can be very stuck in their ways. Sometimes not enough to do

pros: Vibrant environment and multicultural workplace. Very interesting people working on very interesting projects. Usually there is plenty of support if you ask for it.
cons: Engineering and science only school (similar to european polytechnics) therefore expect this to be reflected to the ratio of male/female in the work environment. Usually demanding and stressful when deadlines are approaching.

review_title: Disastrous research experience as an undergraduate in the High Energy Physics Department
pros:
The College is a top level research institution.
It looks great on your CV.
cons:
The group I took part in was badly managed, understaffed and has a terrible social ambiance.
No pay.
Supervision was horrible, until I switched supervisor at the end, with not enough time to finish the project

pros: You never know what new experience the day is going to bring, very varied environment so you never get bored.
cons: Management redtape and management bias when it comes to enuring that all team members carry out their duties effectively.

pros:
Excellent support- both academically and financially.
Exciting and new area of Materials Science we were delving into- great atmosphere in the college and in London
cons: Did not see many other UROP studetns

pros: Very good industry connections. Good understanding of business processes. Working with some very inspiring and intelligent individuals
cons: Too business like. A lot of pressure. Not treated as an intelligent individual, but mostly as a pair of hands. Too many managers!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Kensington, England
pros: Good working hours, lots of scope for secondments, good holidays and well paid.
cons: During my time, I had experience of lots of different departments.  The culture has a slight oppressiveness to it.  There's a conservative tone, and they're heavy on aping Oxbrige.  Quite male and stifled.

job_title: Clinical Data Manager in Paddington, England
pros: Flexibility, good conditions, generous pension, understanding bosses, my Unit Director is awesomely inspirational, reasonable sick leave, paternity leave and exceptional circumstance leave.... Very good salary considering the range of responsibilities in the role
cons: None at all whatsoever...Rien, nada, zip, zilch.

pros: Great working environment with the potential to find dynamic youthful team that has great social interaction outside of the work place. Ability to work in the center of London within the South Kensington Campus which is a rare opportunity for young people.
cons: Can often be isolated and receive unsubstantial support from supervising officers.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in South Kensington, England
pros:
Great admin staff making paperwork move through swiftly.
High budget for research, many opportunities for new funding and continued research.
Respect for postdocs, allowing better collaboration with different PIs
cons: Rather difficult to progress to higher level jobs at Imperial - there should be better support for hiring in-house rather than importing lecturers.

review_title: Very Inspiring place to work in, but little career progress help
pros: A world leading institution, driving innovation and sustainability
cons: Too corporate for a university, not doing what it preaches on sustainability, little career career development prospects unless you are on an academic path

pros: It is a place where many good ideas meat other evolve
cons: it is focused too much on how to attract money into projects than into the projects themselves

review_title: A good fulfilling experience at Imperial College
pros: Acquire many transferrable skills such as analytical skills, teamworking skills, organizational skills, quantitative skills, problem solving skills, leadership skills and many more.
cons: Work may get too theoretical with a relatively large emphasis on getting good grades. Have to push certain departments to use their connections to help you get internships

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: Post doc development center is an excellent facility that isn’t available at many universities – providing an array of training and coaching for further academic or non-academic careers
cons: The cons very much depends on which campus you end up at – for example at the Hammersmith campus the facilities are terrible

pros:
I did an undergrad in biochemistry:
A lot of resources available, high standards and high achieving environment, specialised, good location, international environment
cons:
-too much pressure
-too many deadlines and not enough time to execute them properly
-virtually no work-life balance, you can hardly do anything but study
-this reflects in poor social environment on the campus

pros: Working for one of the best universities in the world is motivating. They have international staff and you fit easily.
cons: As in a lot of big companies there is a communication problem, but not a big deal.

pros:
Lots of opportunities for CPD at post-doctoral level
Interesting and stimulating environment, if you go looking for it
Career support for academics
cons: Not a lot of real collaboration between departments, or even within departments (in my limited experience in an Engineering department)

pros: Well paid for a PhD position. Work with intelligent people. Access to good research facilities. Free health club membership. Good location (South Kensington, London).
cons: The work involved long hours, including several overnight working stints. The university is a high pressure environment and you have to work hard to keep up.

review_title: Good experience, but no future with Brexit
pros: The university and the academic staff are amazing. It is very easy to work at Imperial, there are excellent facilities and services.
cons: Brexit and the final conditions between Europe and the UK are not clear and It is very difficult  to research without knowing where are new founding.

review_title: Decent conditions but not too much freedom in research topic
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England
pros: You have a large variety of people around doing research, the environment is very international and multidisciplinary. It's friendly and the benefits are good.
cons: The office area is very bad. You do not get independence for space and research topic which is crucial to creative thinking.

review_title: PhD in Materials Science at Imperial College
pros:
Big place, lots going on
Academic staff usually helpful
Lots of funding opportunities for equipment/travel etc
Many opportunities to earn money on the side
cons:
Without initiative easy to fall under the radar

If you do not start in the October intake there isn't much of a welcome 

Experience highly dependent on supervisor

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in London, England
pros: Very clever Colleagues who can inspire you and are mostly helpful. It depends of course on what you make of it.
cons: Some Core facilities could be much better organized. The pay could be higher, but it is not that bad either.

pros: challenging work and environment, very smart and international set of colleagues, excellent location at South Kensington, good post doctoral development centre
cons: long hours, no room for advancement beyond temporary post-doc contracts, no full time employment available, departments are disconnected from each other and there is some animosity between them

review_title: An interesting and quirky place to work
job_title: Head of Equality Diversity and Inclusion in London, England
pros: Depending on the department, a flexible approach to working, nice setting in central London, a decent salary and benefits.
cons: Sometimes a bit chaotic but still able to function

review_title: Great place to work, but some managers will ruin it
pros: Lots of perks and exciting opportunities
cons: While there has been some surface effort to curb bullying by management, there are still instances. HR can't do much as staff are scared of repercussions to their careers if they formally report.

job_title: PhD Research Scholar in London, England
pros: Good location, good benefits, like free gym membership and discount for tfl. Students' pubs are cheap nad the food is always very good
cons: Salary is too low to live in London and work/life balance depends a lot on the supervisor. The food in the canteen is not very good and also pricey

pros: Great atmosphere, you really get the feeling the organisation is a good for society. Generally not too pressured, management very open.
cons:
The tension between the academic mission and financial realities is sometimes difficult to manage and can result in conflicting priorities.

Some long timers who are resistant to change and are coasting.

pros: The work environment at Imperial is friendly, competitive and motivating. The facilities are world-class, and there are several opportunities to develop and hone professional skills.
cons: Imperial has several campuses located quite far from each other, which sometimes limits the easy access to all the expertise Imperial owns.

review_title: Fantastic science, great people, poor management and communication
pros:
Cutting edge research 
Generally good support structure for junior researchers
Competitive salary
cons:
Research groups can be very isolated with a lack of communication between them
Depending on the PI management can range from great to very poor
Needless levels of bureaucracy can be frustrating and difficult to navigate

pros:
Professional and technical learning are useful. 
Lectures recording available
Most lecturers good at explaining definitions and examples
Responsible staff
cons:
Heavy pressure and sophisticated  theoretical content really struggling.
Fewer interesting extra-curricular activities
Increasingly decreasing level of food

pros: Flexibility, benefits package, many great colleagues, diversity, location.
cons: Limited incentive to excel, mediocrity and poor behaviours tolerated and even rewarded, HR not Talent Management, bureacracy, 'Imperial expectations' are written but not lived.

job_title: Student Caller in South Kensington, England
pros:
Pretty decent pay for what you would receive as a student, around £10 - 12 an hour. 
Flexible working hours, requiring a minimum of 2, 3-hour shifts a week.
cons:
Can take a while to get use to the system. 
Have to take an induction training course over a weekend without pay

pros: State of the art equipment, prestigious supervisor and research team, plenty of career development opportunities with workshops, lectures, training, etc.
cons: Expensive are of london to live/work, stress, long working hours, excellence is expected as the norm.

pros: Good location and a centre of world leading research across many departments. Lots of opportunities present themselves.
cons: Young researchers are generally poorly paid and have to live in central London. Despite being very nice, the West London location is quite quiet, not as cultured and lively as East London.

pros: Location, access to skills development courses, good leave entitlements (if your boss allows you to take it...)
cons: No research support, too much middle management and form-filling slows productivity to a snails pace, abuse of PhD and post-docs is rife and nothing is ever done to protect them, no opportunity for advancement, many PIs and higher management don't care about their staff or their career at all

pros: Great research quality and enjoyable place to work in, good HR support, good facilities and good access to funding when needed.
cons: In my department, not enough career support for young researchers. I know other departments at Imperial are better for career support.

pros: Great minds at work , large potential to develop. Central London... long scientific history .... good reputation.... big names.... work on potentially interesting problems
cons: Feels like a ghetto at times. Over emphasis of being Brit. Poor salary for London living ... research output of theoretical value , perhaps less verified. Cult following type.

review_title: Great place to work on a variety of exciting projects helping the college enhance its research and academic teachings
pros: Great place, talented people and exciting smart working facilities for ICT department.
cons: Business stakeholder decisions may take long time due to confusion or not knowing what they want which may delay project progress

pros: Imperial College focuses in a systematic way on maximising economic and societal impact of the work, while maintaining genuine academic curiosity.
cons: The salaries, as in all academia, can be below market for the skillset required, but consulting and directorship opportunities can more than make up for that.

job_title: Marie Curie Fellow in London, England
pros: Top university with high visibility worldwide. Easier access to funding or scholarships. Organisation is perfect.
cons: Academia job in a top university, you must deliver otherwise it quickly turns from an opportunity into a waste of time. They salary is good, but London life is very expensive..

review_title: Research Assistant at Imperial College London
pros: Casual, some flexibility, fixed working hours, no clients, more than avg holidays, lots of independent work (could be a con), able to work towards a degree such as PhD if wanted
cons: limited progression of pay, only for people who want to stay in academia

pros: Great learning environment. No rush for publications. Technology development and fundamental research are a priority.  There is a 'postdoc development center' which works with skill development. Lots of option for networking and learning.
cons: The campus is small, small seating space.

review_title: I'm proud of working at Imperial College, one of the most famous universities in the world
pros:
1. Very good working environment
2. Good training courses.
3. Flaxible working time
4. Very talent colleagues.
cons:
hard to make a long term plan, have to think about the contract year by year.
no hope for career prompt.

pros: It is a nice place, good atmosphere, a lot of opportunites to improve career.  It is also in a very nice location.
cons: One must have a very good work ethic and constantly seek improvements to succeed at Imperial college.  Work hard, and you will succeed.

pros: Good enviroment with really nice buildings and labs, smart people, sharp professors and nice equipment altough there is not enough space for everyone
cons: Too much burocracy they need to be faster in the paperwork, sometimes just to have access to a lab you need to wait a week.

job_title: MSC Finance & Accounting Student in London, England

pros: The faculty is great, supportive and approachable. A lot of incentives for students who want to take initiative.

pros:
-Great people
-Great reputation
- Flexible work environment

pros: Great opportunities. Work is plentiful and satisfying. Hard work is the norm and expected but well rewarded. Strong links to industry.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in London, England

pros: good infrastructure facilities, nice set of people to work with, very accessible as it's located in central london, great campus.

pros: Supports student entrepreneurs in anyway they can, which is a lot of ways

review_title: Undergraduate and post-graduate degree study and part time work

pros: Good pay rate and benefits within London, diversity and equality is top rated. Gay friendly and proactive in making change.

cons: Too much focus on margins and the bottom line. Academic institutions can't innovate in a straightjacket.

too many students to look after and no much time left for your own work

pros: I am a parent. There is a nursery at South Kensington Campus, Imperial College, where my kids go to. It is convenient to me so I can come to work with them and go home together.

review_title: Great, but doesn't quite live up to its reputation
